channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: There Are Two Chinas, and America Must Understand Both
item.description: The technological success that has captured the attention of many in the United States is one aspect of the Chinese economy. There’s another, gloomy o...

item.title: Good news for night owls: When you need sleep is determined not by laziness, but chronotype. Here’s what that means
item.description: When you need sleep depends on what’s called your chronotype—your body’s natural inclination towards certain times of day.

item.title: RFK Jr. Swims in D.C.’s Rock Creek, Which Flows With Sewage and Bacteria
item.description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health secretary, shared photos of himself and his grandchildren swimming in waters that handle sewer overflow.

item.title: Half of the world’s cars won’t be fully electric by 2040—Renault and Geely are betting big on hybrids to fill the gap
item.description: Horse Powertrain’s modular hybrid tech aims to bridge the global EV gap—and help automakers scale clean mobility faster across diverse markets.

item.title: Car trouble: Can the French car industry recover to pre-pandemic levels?
item.description: Sales are down, factories are closing—but profits remain high. As EVs, offshoring, and China reshape the road ahead, France’s car sector faces a recko...

item.title: Stripe’s billionaire Collison brothers say remote work solves the ‘two-body problem’ faced by working couples
item.description: Stripe president John Collison cautioned against RTO mandates, saying they catered to the “bottom 5% of the company.”

item.title: Germany Has a Long History of U.S. Investment. That May Be Changing.
item.description: German companies invest more than three times as much in the United States as American companies do in Germany, but they are starting to rethink that ...

item.title: This Is Not the Saudi Arabia Trump Visited Before
item.description: America’s national security could benefit from a successful Trump visit to Saudi Arabia — and suffer from a bad one.

item.title: The U.S. Army Is Finally Pivoting Toward Future Threats
item.description: A new doctrine will transform the kinds of weapons America uses, how they are purchased and how fast they get into the hands of soldiers.

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte Is Expected to Again Become Mayor of Davao City
item.description: Former President Rodrigo Duterte, who faces international court charges of crimes against humanity, appears to have been elected mayor of Davao City. ...

item.title: Starmer Pledges to Cut U.K. Immigration
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer said his government was “taking back control of our borders,” weeks after a right-wing populist party, Reform U.K., made g...

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: President Trump’s visit to the Gulf region.

item.title: Trump is hosting a dinner for the biggest buyers of his memecoin. The guest list is now set—and many of the winners are foreign nationals
item.description: Democratic lawmakers have said the crypto confab is a clear case of corruption.

item.title: Farmers Sued Over Deleted Climate Data. So the Government Will Put It Back.
item.description: The Agriculture Department pledged to restore online climate information that farmers said helped them do business, but which officials had deleted.

item.title: Palestinian Authority Lifting Ban on Al Jazeera in West Bank
item.description: The authority offered scant information about why it issued the ban in January, and it maintained that stance in announcing that it was rescinding it.
